<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RESTAURANT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/08/03/nyc-restaurants-bars-facing-rent-crisis?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Empty Chairs at Empty Tables
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Restaurant table without patrons" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xOTc0L3Jlc3RhdXJhbnRfdGFibGVfd2l0aG91dF9wYXRyb25zLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Restaurants <a href="https://apnews.com/60a4e9a873593cc149975c936ef9cf44?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">across the country</a> are folding, but nowhere is the crisis more pronounced than the Brew’s own stomping ground. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In July, 83% of NYC bars, restaurants, and nightlife establishments weren’t able to pay full rent, according to an <a href="https://thenycalliance.org/assets/documents/informationitems/jlBDT.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">NYC Hospitality Alliance survey</a> of 471 businesses. 37% couldn’t pay at all.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Some landlords have tried working with battered tenants: Almost 29% waived some rent. But struggling with bills of their own, most did not. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">NYC’s commercial tenant eviction moratorium expires tomorrow. The Hospitality Alliance has <a href="https://gothamist.com/food/over-one-third-nyc-restaurants-and-bars-surveyed-couldnt-pay-last-months-rent?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">asked</a> for an extension, as well as extra support for landlords. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The city has tried helping</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">NYC allowed margs-to-go and, with indoor dining banned indefinitely, set up the Open Restaurants program to convert sidewalks, parking spaces, and even streets into outdoor dining spaces. Nearly 10,000 restaurants <a href="https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2020/08/03/nycs-outdoor-dining-program-will-return-next-year-1304678?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">signed up</a>, helping an estimated 80,000 laid-off employees get back to work.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>But social distancing and reduced capacity means they still aren’t bringing in enough foot traffic to cover expenses. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Open Restaurants runs through October 31, and NYC is considering options to keep it running through winter for al freezing dining. Yesterday, Mayor Bill de Blasio promised it’ll return again next year by June 1. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Big picture</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s not just restaurants. Over 2,800 NYC businesses have <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/03/nyregion/nyc-small-businesses-closing-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">closed</a> since March 1, the most of any major U.S. city, according to Yelp. Of those, minority- and female-owned businesses were likely the most vulnerable. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And the forecast is cloudier than Isaias. Small businesses account for more than 3 million jobs in the city, and so far, they’ve already lost 520,000. When the pandemic eases, a third of NYC’s 240,000 small businesses may be gone, per the Partnership for New York City.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here: </strong>100+ execs from some of the U.S.’ biggest companies sent a letter to Congress <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/312e6aa2-be03-4963-a951-1b820dea671e?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">requesting</a> more small business aid.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOPOLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/08/03/chinese-government-citizens-attack-proposed-tiktok-sale?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The TikTok Drama: How It’s Playing in China
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not well. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">By now, you’re aware that the U.S. government has essentially <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/08/02/microsoft-tiktok-thrown-off-trumps-pledge-ban-app?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">forced</a> Chinese tech company ByteDance to sell its TikTok app to an American firm to keep operating in the U.S. That American firm appears to be Microsoft. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, both Chinese citizens and the government <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/microsofts-talks-to-buy-tiktoks-u-s-operations-raise-concerns-in-china-11596465664?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">went on the attack</a>. The Communist Party tabloid Global Times called a forced sale the “hunting and looting” of TikTok. And hundreds of social media users <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/08/03/chinese-netizens-criticize-bytedance-ceo/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">took aim</a> at ByteDance founder and CEO Zhang Yiming, who they accused of capitulating to the U.S.—China’s top economic and political rival. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In a letter to staff yesterday, Zhang conceded, “We understand their decision in the current macro environment.”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“Their” refers to CFIUS, the U.S. agency that investigates mergers for national security concerns.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>On the surface, ByteDance resembles another Chinese tech company, Huawei, which has faced U.S. opposition as it’s tried to expand globally. But Huawei is more strategically important to the Chinese government than ByteDance, the <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/0c42dc7c-b927-477a-90b7-a202bbe4bc50?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">FT reports</a>, so Beijing isn’t likely to retaliate against the U.S. over TikTok.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here: </strong>Yesterday, President Trump <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tiktok-navarro/trump-u-s-should-get-substantial-portion-of-tiktok-operations-sale-price-idUSKBN24Z1SM?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a> the U.S. government should get a “substantial portion” of TikTok’s sale for “making it possible for this deal to happen.” </p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/08/03/google-announces-adt-partnership-new-trio-smartphones?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Google Starts Week With a Double Shot
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<img alt="Pixel 4a" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xOTcxL3BpeGVsXzRhLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Google</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Google brushed off last week’s antitrust drama with two big announcements yesterday. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Announcement #1:</strong> <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-google-adt-stake/google-to-buy-66-stake-in-adt-in-home-security-push-idUSKBN24Z1A6?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">A 6.6% stake</a> worth $450 million in home security company ADT, which will sell, install, and service Google’s Nest <span>line of home security devices</span><span>. The goal is for Nest to become the “</span><a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/3/21352360/google-adt-investment-nest-smart-home-security-alarms-machine-learning-alerts?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cornerstone</a><span>” of ADT’s smart home business.</span></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>By linking up with one of the leading home security providers, Google’s going toe-to-toe with Amazon’s Echo smart devices and Ring home security system.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Announcement #2: </strong>A <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/3/21352032/google-pixel-5-4a-5g-price-release-date-specs?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">trio of new Pixel smartphones</a>, including the $349 Pixel 4A that’ll start shipping this month. With competition tight in the <$500 smartphone market, Google <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/03/technology/personaltech/google-pixel-4a-review.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">packed</a> the 4A with the Pixel’s famous camera, a good battery, lots of storage, and priced it lower than Apple’s budget iPhone SE.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The new phone won’t get much love from carriers, which are focused on 5G compatibility, but Google also announced the Pixel 5 and Pixel 4A 5G, coming this fall with next-gen network support.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>Samsung <a href="https://www.tomsguide.com/news/how-to-watch-samsung-unpacked-galaxy-note-20-galaxy-watch-3-galaxy-buds-live-and-more?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">answers</a> Google’s call at its Galaxy Unpacked event tomorrow.</p>

<img class="story-header-image" alt="The Rock gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/TT7JW4Qm7uaNW/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But for once, that’s a great place to be. Yesterday, a group consisting of Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson, his business partner and ex-wife Dany Garcia, and private equity firm RedBird Capital <a href="https://www.sportico.com/2020/leagues/football/dwayne-the-rock-johnson-buys-xfl-for-15-million-with-redbird-capital-1234610422/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">agreed to purchase</a> the XFL for $15 million, Sportico reports. An auction for the league was set to begin just hours after the announcement.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory:</strong> The XFL, a fan-favorite experimental football league, is the brainchild of WWE CEO Vince McMahon. After an inaugural season in 2001 that ended in bankruptcy, the league was resurrected in 2018 before again <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/13/sports/football/xfl-bankruptcy-vince-mcmahon.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">succumbing to bankruptcy</a> in April after the coronavirus pandemic cut its return season short.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The Rock is literally the perfect buyer</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Miami Hurricanes football player turned wrestling phenomenon turned <a href="https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/dwayne-the-rock-johnson-eats-about-821-pounds-of-cod-per-year/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cod's worst nigthmare</a> turned Kevin Hart sidekick is an expert promoter, and says his decision to <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/03/investing/xfl-sold-dwayne-the-rock-johnson/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">buy the league</a> was "rooted deeply in two things—my passion for the game and my desire to always take care of the fans.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>don’t expect any football right away. The XFL will look to <a href="https://www.axios.com/xfl-sale-dwayne-johnson-the-rock-76120440-b139-4e15-98f1-aa676f188641.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">secure media partners</a> before even thinking about launching a new season, Axios says.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/08/03/snapchat-adds-feature-compete-tiktok?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
SnapTok? TikChat?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Spiderman pointing meme" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xOTcyL3NwaWRlcm1hbl9wb2ludGluZ19tZW1lLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Spiderman meme</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Remember when Snapchat released Stories and then seemingly every other social network hopped on the bandwagon? Now Snap is the bandwagon-hopper. Yesterday, it announced it's adding “a robust” music catalog to the app, giving users the <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/3/21352680/snapchat-music-embed-tiktok-competitor?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ability to incorporate music</a> in their Snaps. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s a subtle-but-not-so-subtle bid to attract a potentially fractured TikTok audience that’s <a href="https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/business/story/2020-07-31/tiktok-byte-dance-china-hollywood-creators-lil-nas-mayer?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unclear</a> about the future of the app in the U.S.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How it’s different:</strong> Unlike TikTok, there <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/08/03/snapchat-to-take-on-tiktok-with-a-new-music-powered-featuring-rolling-out-this-fall/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">won’t be a public feed</a> where you can browse through videos. And when a user clicks on a song featured in a Snap, they’ll be redirected to listen to the full song and get info about the artist and album, rather than seeing other videos using the same song.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> With the <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/07/16/instagram-confirms-its-tiktok-rival-reels-will-launch-in-the-us-in-early-august/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">looming entry</a> of Instagram Reels, the short-form video app market is getting crowded. But Snap says its new feature is meant to capitalize on Snapchat's existing strengths—facilitating connections with friends (and now artists) on a one-to-one basis. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
<div>
<div>Morning Brew’s Casting for Our Next Podcast</div>
</div>
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>Like most of you, we've have been working from home since March. This has been great for social distancing, but not so good for social debating.<br> <br>We miss going at it IRL; there’s nothing better than that feeling when you know you’ve made the perfect point in a debate. But beyond that, we miss laughing in the office together over Finance Twitter, media memes, and all the other oddities of the biz world.<br> <br>So we’re gonna do something about it the only way we know how: with a new podcast. It’ll be an audio + video business talk show featuring two hosts that will become a go-to source for engaging, exciting opinions on all things business. They’ll cover everything from earnings reports to business trends to whatever a certain Mars-obsessed CEO did that week.<br> <br>And with the perfect two hosts at the helm, we’re going to incorporate the best of the best: the banter from <em>Pivot</em>, the smart comedy from <em>The Daily Show</em>, the emotion from <em>Mad Money</em>, and the analysis from <em>Stratechery</em>.</div>
<div> </div>
<div>Think you’ve got what it takes to be a pod pro? <a href="https://jobs.lever.co/morningbrew/e9452364-7ab5-4e2e-898d-b4147f6de9b3?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" data-saferedirecturl="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://jobs.lever.co/morningbrew/e9452364-7ab5-4e2e-898d-b4147f6de9b3&source=gmail&ust=1596575540803000&usg=AFQjCNFmeTts3CdKzXvqzkYXodpc22FgrA" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Apply to be a host.</a> </div>
</td>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Written by
<a href="https://twitter.com/tobydoyhowell" class="link" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Toby Howell</a>, <a href="https://twitter.com/Neal_Freyman" class="link" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Neal Freyman</a>, and <a href="https://twitter.com/its_ahickey" class="link" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Alex Hickey</a>

Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRestaurants \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/60a4e9a873593cc149975c936ef9cf44?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eacross the country\u003c/a\u003e are folding, but nowhere is the crisis more pronounced than the Brew’s own stomping ground. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn July, 83% of NYC bars, restaurants, and nightlife establishments weren’t able to pay full rent, according to an \u003ca href=\"https://thenycalliance.org/assets/documents/informationitems/jlBDT.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNYC Hospitality Alliance survey\u003c/a\u003e of 471 businesses. 37% couldn’t pay at all.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSome landlords have tried working with battered tenants: Almost 29% waived some rent. But struggling with bills of their own, most did not. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNYC’s commercial tenant eviction moratorium expires tomorrow. The Hospitality Alliance has \u003ca href=\"https://gothamist.com/food/over-one-third-nyc-restaurants-and-bars-surveyed-couldnt-pay-last-months-rent?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003easked\u003c/a\u003e for an extension, as well as extra support for landlords. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe city has tried helping\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNYC allowed margs-to-go and, with indoor dining banned indefinitely, set up the Open Restaurants program to convert sidewalks, parking spaces, and even streets into outdoor dining spaces. Nearly 10,000 restaurants \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2020/08/03/nycs-outdoor-dining-program-will-return-next-year-1304678?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esigned up\u003c/a\u003e, helping an estimated 80,000 laid-off employees get back to work.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBut social distancing and reduced capacity means they still aren’t bringing in enough foot traffic to cover expenses. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOpen Restaurants runs through October 31, and NYC is considering options to keep it running through winter for al freezing dining. Yesterday, Mayor Bill de Blasio promised it’ll return again next year by June 1. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBig picture\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s not just restaurants. Over 2,800 NYC businesses have \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/03/nyregion/nyc-small-businesses-closing-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eclosed\u003c/a\u003e since March 1, the most of any major U.S. city, according to Yelp. Of those, minority- and female-owned businesses were likely the most vulnerable. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd the forecast is cloudier than Isaias. Small businesses account for more than 3 million jobs in the city, and so far, they’ve already lost 520,000. When the pandemic eases, a third of NYC’s 240,000 small businesses may be gone, per the Partnership for New York City.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we’re here: \u003c/strong\u003e100+ execs from some of the U.S.’ biggest companies sent a letter to Congress \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/312e6aa2-be03-4963-a951-1b820dea671e?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erequesting\u003c/a\u003e more small business aid.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewent on the attack\u003c/a\u003e. The Communist Party tabloid Global Times called a forced sale the “hunting and looting” of TikTok. And hundreds of social media users \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/08/03/chinese-netizens-criticize-bytedance-ceo/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etook aim\u003c/a\u003e at ByteDance founder and CEO Zhang Yiming, who they accused of capitulating to the U.S.—China’s top economic and political rival. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn a letter to staff yesterday, Zhang conceded, “We understand their decision in the current macro environment.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“Their” refers to CFIUS, the U.S. agency that investigates mergers for national security concerns.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eOn the surface, ByteDance resembles another Chinese tech company, Huawei, which has faced U.S. opposition as it’s tried to expand globally. But Huawei is more strategically important to the Chinese government than ByteDance, the \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/0c42dc7c-b927-477a-90b7-a202bbe4bc50?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eFT reports\u003c/a\u003e, so Beijing isn’t likely to retaliate against the U.S. over TikTok.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we’re here: \u003c/strong\u003eYesterday, President Trump \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tiktok-navarro/trump-u-s-should-get-substantial-portion-of-tiktok-operations-sale-price-idUSKBN24Z1SM?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e the U.S. government should get a “substantial portion” of TikTok’s sale for “making it possible for this deal to happen.” \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGoogle brushed off last week’s antitrust drama with two big announcements yesterday. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-google-adt-stake/google-to-buy-66-stake-in-adt-in-home-security-push-idUSKBN24Z1A6?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eA 6.6% stake\u003c/a\u003e worth $450 million in home security company ADT, which will sell, install, and service Google’s Nest \u003cspan\u003eline of home security devices\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. The goal is for Nest to become the “\u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/3/21352360/google-adt-investment-nest-smart-home-security-alarms-machine-learning-alerts?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecornerstone\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e” of ADT’s smart home business.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBy linking up with one of the leading home security providers, Google’s going toe-to-toe with Amazon’s Echo smart devices and Ring home security system.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAnnouncement #2: \u003c/strong\u003eA \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/3/21352032/google-pixel-5-4a-5g-price-release-date-specs?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etrio of new Pixel smartphones\u003c/a\u003e, including the $349 Pixel 4A that’ll start shipping this month. With competition tight in the \u003c$500 smartphone market, Google \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/03/technology/personaltech/google-pixel-4a-review.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epacked\u003c/a\u003e the 4A with the Pixel’s famous camera, a good battery, lots of storage, and priced it lower than Apple’s budget iPhone SE.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe new phone won’t get much love from carriers, which are focused on 5G compatibility, but Google also announced the Pixel 5 and Pixel 4A 5G, coming this fall with next-gen network support.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eanswers\u003c/a\u003e Google’s call at its Galaxy Unpacked event tomorrow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut for once, that’s a great place to be. Yesterday, a group consisting of Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson, his business partner and ex-wife Dany Garcia, and private equity firm RedBird Capital \u003ca href=\"https://www.sportico.com/2020/leagues/football/dwayne-the-rock-johnson-buys-xfl-for-15-million-with-redbird-capital-1234610422/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eagreed to purchase\u003c/a\u003e the XFL for $15 million, Sportico reports. An auction for the league was set to begin just hours after the announcement.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e The XFL, a fan-favorite experimental football league, is the brainchild of WWE CEO Vince McMahon. After an inaugural season in 2001 that ended in bankruptcy, the league was resurrected in 2018 before again \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/13/sports/football/xfl-bankruptcy-vince-mcmahon.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuccumbing to bankruptcy\u003c/a\u003e in April after the coronavirus pandemic cut its return season short.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe Rock is literally the perfect buyer\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Miami Hurricanes football player turned wrestling phenomenon turned \u003ca href=\"https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/dwayne-the-rock-johnson-eats-about-821-pounds-of-cod-per-year/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecod's worst nigthmare\u003c/a\u003e turned Kevin Hart sidekick is an expert promoter, and says his decision to \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/03/investing/xfl-sold-dwayne-the-rock-johnson/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebuy the league\u003c/a\u003e was \"rooted deeply in two things—my passion for the game and my desire to always take care of the fans.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003edon’t expect any football right away. The XFL will look to \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/xfl-sale-dwayne-johnson-the-rock-76120440-b139-4e15-98f1-aa676f188641.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esecure media partners\u003c/a\u003e before even thinking about launching a new season, Axios says.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F08%2F03%2Fdwyane-rock-johnson-becomes-part-owner-xfl\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; TikChat?\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Spiderman pointing meme\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xOTcyL3NwaWRlcm1hbl9wb2ludGluZ19tZW1lLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eSpiderman meme\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRemember when Snapchat released Stories and then seemingly every other social network hopped on the bandwagon? Now Snap is the bandwagon-hopper. Yesterday, it announced it's adding “a robust” music catalog to the app, giving users the \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/3/21352680/snapchat-music-embed-tiktok-competitor?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eability to incorporate music\u003c/a\u003e in their Snaps. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s a subtle-but-not-so-subtle bid to attract a potentially fractured TikTok audience that’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/business/story/2020-07-31/tiktok-byte-dance-china-hollywood-creators-lil-nas-mayer?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunclear\u003c/a\u003e about the future of the app in the U.S.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow it’s different:\u003c/strong\u003e Unlike TikTok, there \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/08/03/snapchat-to-take-on-tiktok-with-a-new-music-powered-featuring-rolling-out-this-fall/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewon’t be a public feed\u003c/a\u003e where you can browse through videos. And when a user clicks on a song featured in a Snap, they’ll be redirected to listen to the full song and get info about the artist and album, rather than seeing other videos using the same song.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e With the \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/07/16/instagram-confirms-its-tiktok-rival-reels-will-launch-in-the-us-in-early-august/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elooming entry\u003c/a\u003e of Instagram Reels, the short-form video app market is getting crowded. But Snap says its new feature is meant to capitalize on Snapchat's existing strengths—facilitating connections with friends (and now artists) on a one-to-one basis. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL
